newsitem.title: JAPAN: Tokyo naphtha sinks after sharp drop in crude.
newsitem.headline: Tokyo naphtha sinks after sharp drop in crude.

text.p: Naphtha prices fell in afternoon Tokyo trade on Wednesday in reaction to a sharp drop in crude oil prices on overseas markets, traders said.
Open-spec naphtha for second-half July was quoted around $213.50/215.00 per tonne.
First-half August delivery was assessed at $214.00/215.50, compared with late Tuesday's levels of $217.75/218.75.
It was said to have been traded at $218.50 in early afternoon trade on Tuesday.
Second-half August was traded at $218.00 on Tuesday.

In inter-month naphtha spreads, second-half July/second-half August was discussed at minus $1.00/minus 25 cents. It changed hands between South Korean trading houses at minus 25 cents in Tuesday's trade, market sources said.
In low sulphur waxy residue (LSWR) trading, demand from Japanese power firms, which are major customers of Indonesian LSWR cargoes, remained slack, traders said.

Although end-April fuel oil stocks at Japan's 10 regional power utilities fell seven percent from a year ago to 2.23 million kilolitres, lower stock levels have so far failed to spur the power firms to seek spot cargoes, they said.
